New Records: Quinton de Kock's half-century off 22 balls equalled the fastest fifty of the tournament.
Quinton de Kock's 49 runs in the Powerplay are the most by a South African batter at a Men's T20 World Cup.
Key Match Events: Anrich Nortje bowled a good final over and took a crucial wicket.
Aiden Markram took a significant catch to dismiss Harry Brook.
Baartman got Moeen Ali out with a short ball.
Anrich Nortje took a spectacular catch to dismiss Jonny Bairstow.
Jos Buttler ran out Heinrich Klaasen with a direct hit.
Jos Buttler took a leaping one-handed catch to dismiss Quinton de Kock.
Reeza Hendricks was dismissed after a 86-run opening partnership with Quinton de Kock.
Quinton de Kock was dropped on 58 by Mark Wood.
Quinton de Kock scored a half-century off 22 balls.
South Africa's opening partnership of 86 runs was their fifth-highest at T20 World Cups.
Pre-Game Insights: Jos Buttler put South Africa in on a fresh pitch and anticipated some swing in humid, windy conditions.
South Africa brought back Ottneil Baartman for Tabraiz Shamsi.
England were unchanged after their win over West Indies.
Reece Topley and Moeen Ali have good records against Quinton de Kock.
South Africa included only one specialist spinner, Keshav Maharaj, and may turn to Aiden Markram.
Post-Match Reflections: South Africa remain unbeaten at this T20 World Cup and are now 6/6.
England's NRR remains positive, and a win against the USA should see them through to the semis.
Miscellaneous Highlights: South Africa defended what seemed an under-par total and recovered from a misread of the conditions.
England's spinners were more economical compared to their seamers.
South Africa's run-rate after the Powerplay was 7.14.
Mark Wood was expensive in his second over, conceding 13 runs.
South Africa's second-most productive Powerplay at the tournament so far.
Quinton de Kock took 17 runs off Jofra Archer's opening over, which cost 21 runs.
